body: @mejas: Great to see such detailed stack, thanks! Ever tried loading the model with onnxruntime Python API, if so is the memory curve similar?

Hi @RandySheriffH,
Thanks for taking time to reply. I'm not too familiar with the python tools for memory profiling, but I gave it a shot just in case. I ran the following script in combination with the `memory_profiler` tool available in python:
```
import onnxruntime as rt
@profile
def my_func():
    session = rt.InferenceSession('DifferentModelSizes_80MB.onnx')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    my_func()
```
The profiler gave me the following results:
```
Line #    Mem usage    Increment  Occurences   Line Contents
============================================================
     3   38.836 MiB   38.836 MiB           1   @profile
     4                                         def my_func():
     5  797.113 MiB  758.277 MiB           1       session = rt.InferenceSession('DifferentModelSizes_80MB.onnx')
```
I did see that allocated memory spiked to around 1.1GB via Task Manager (same as the C# program I created), but noticed that memory quickly got freed compared to the C# one. I don't have deeper insight into the python runtime as it is something I am not familiar with, however I find it odd since the CLR has pretty fine-tuned GC algorithms (even for interop libraries like onnxruntime).

Would like to hear your thoughts on the matter, thanks!

issue.title: Possible Memory leak in CXX Api

labels.name: stale
labels.description: issues that have not been addressed in a while; categorized by a bot

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

Possible Memory leak in CXX Api. I use onnxruntime in my server. Within three months, its memory usage increased from 30% to 90% . I wirte my code as the demo

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/csharp/test/Microsoft.ML.OnnxRuntime.EndToEndTests.Capi/CXX_Api_Sample.cpp

these errors alse happend in my code, how can I fixed them ?

I alse see other issue for memory leak:

https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/6058
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/5176

- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): binary
- ONNX Runtime version: onnxruntime-1.6.0
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source): g++ 7.5

issue.title: Replace Tensorflow/Keras-based inference (`.h5`) with onnxruntime (`.ONNX`)

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: category: improves performance/results of an existing feature

repository.name: spinalcordtoolbox
repository.description: Comprehensive and open-source library of analysis tools for MRI of the spinal cord.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
<!-- Hi, and thank you for submitting a Pull Request! The checklist below is a brief summary of steps found in the NeuroPoly Contributing Guidelines, which can be found here: https://intranet.neuro.polymtl.ca/geek-tips/contributing. 
-->

## Checklist

#### GitHub

- [x] I've given this PR a concise, self-descriptive, and meaningful title
- [x] I've linked relevant issues in the PR body
- [x] I've applied [the relevant labels](https://intranet.neuro.polymtl.ca/geek-tips/contributing#pr-labels-a-href-pr-labels-id-pr-labels-a) to this PR
- [x] I've applied a [release milestone](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/milestones) (major, minor, patch) in line with [Semantic Versioning guidelines](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/wiki/Misc%3A-Creating-a-new-release#convention-for-naming-releases) 
- [x] I've assigned a reviewer

<!-- For the title, please observe the following rules:
	- Provide a concise and self-descriptive title
	- Do not include the applicable issue number in the title, do it in the PR body
	- If the PR is not ready for review, convert it to a draft.
-->

#### PR contents

- [ ] I've consulted [SCT's internal developer documentation](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/wiki) to ensure my contribution is in line with any relevant design decisions
- [x] I've added [relevant tests](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/wiki/Programming%3A-Tests) for my contribution
- [ ] I've updated the [relevant documentation](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/wiki/Programming%3A-Documentation) for my changes, including argparse descriptions, docstrings, and ReadTheDocs tutorial pages

## Description
<!-- describe what the PR is about. Explain the approach and possible drawbacks.It's ok to repeat some text from the related issue. -->

This PR eliminates our dependency on Tensorflow/keras by replacing our Keras `.h5` models with equivalent `.ONNX` models.

The changes include:

* Keras model code cleanup (Some issues were fixed in the Keras model code, then the source files were moved into `dev/`)
* `deepseg_` module code cleanup (Source files were moved to a central `deepseg_` module)
* A Jupyter notebook was added to `dev/` to generate ONNX models from the Keras code
* Keras inference was replaced with ONNX inference
* The `CroppedRegion` class in `sct_deepseg_gm` was rewritten (to better support fixed-input ONNX models)
* Every trace of Keras/Tensorflow code was removed from the `spinalcordtoolbox/` package
* Keras/Tensorflow-related dependencies were removed.

All of these changes are explained by individual commits, so I highly recommend using the "Commit" view to review this PR.

## Validation

A second Jupyter notebook,  `keras_vs_onnx_model_output_comparison.ipynb`, is used to ensure that the model output is identical between the `.h5` and `.ONNX` versions.

* I used full-sized data from `sct_example_data` to test all 16 models using Jupyter notebook. For all 16 output image files, the results were identical between the Keras and ONNX versions.
* I then re-ran the Jupyter notebook using `sct_testing_data`. Unfortunately, for smaller inputs (<200x200) into the sct_deepseg_gm model, outputs were _not_ identical (see [this comment](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/pull/3738#discussion_r831592274) for discussion). 
* But, following discussion in one of our SCT meetings, we've deemed this an acceptable change.

The generated files for both Keras and ONNX models are provided here:

* [data_keras.zip](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/files/8399211/data_keras.zip)
* [data_onnx.zip](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/files/8399209/data_onnx.zip)

To validate the new ONNX models yourself, you can either:

* Recompute the Keras and ONNX predictions from scratch using the `keras_vs_onnx_model_output_comparison.ipynb` notebook (difficult -- requires 2 installations of SCT, one from `master` and one from this branch)
* Or, download and extract the `data_keras.zip` files, then only run the validation notebook using this PR branch.

## Benefits

Just to restate the benefits from #3046:

* Installation size decreases from 2.8GB to 2.4GB.
* We no longer have to deal with AVX-related issues, which has been a big blocker in the past for both older CPUs and newer CPUs (M1 macs)
* We no longer have to face Dependabot security warnings due to using an outdated Tensorflow.
* This PR unlocks #3367:
    * You can see a demo of SCT successfully installing on Python 3.8/3.9 in [this action run](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/actions/runs/2000613501), which was built on this separate branch [`jn/3367-support-python-3.8-3.9`](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/commits/jn/3367-support-python-3.8-3.9).

## Linked issues
<!-- If the PR fixes any issues, indicate it here with issue-closing keywords: e.g. Resolves #XX, Fixes #XX, Addresses #XX. Note that if you want multiple issues to be autoclosed on PR merge, you must use the issue-closing verb before each relevant issue: e.g. Resolves #1, Resolves #2 -->

Fixes #3735.
Accomplishes similar goals as #3046.
Supersedes https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/pull/3653.
